values.description: This PR makes it possible to put Qt headers in `src/gui` and automatically `moc` on them. The headers that are already in `include/ignition/gazebo/gui` can't be moved into `src/gui` until Dome.
values.title: Allow putting GUI headers in src/gui and move resources into src/gui

summary.raw: This PR makes it possible to put Qt headers in `src/gui` and automatically `moc` on them. The headers that are already in `include/ignition/gazebo/gui` can't be moved into `src/gui` until Dome.
summary.html: This PR makes it possible to put Qt headers in src/gui and automatically moc on them. The headers that are already in include/ignition/gazebo/gui can't be moved into src/gui until Dome.

values.description:
Warnings: https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-ign-gazebo2-homebrew-amd64/92/warnings10Result/

The Protobuf deprecation was added on version [3.4.0](https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/blob/master/CHANGES.txt#L612).

Our Linux CI is using 3.0.0 and doesn't see the warnings, but homebrew is using 3.11.4.

[Here](https://github.com/protocolbuffers/protobuf/blob/master/src/google/protobuf/stubs/common.h#L82)'s an explanation of `GOOGLE_PROTOBUF_VERSION`.
values.title: 👩‍🌾 Fix protobuf / clang warnings

Our Linux CI is using 3.0.0 and doesn't see the warnings, but homebrew is using 3.11.4.

values.description: This PR allows changing the state of physics objects while simulation is paused. This means, for example, the Component Inspector will be updated after using the Transform tool while simulation is paused.
values.title: Update physics state even when paused (not stepping)

summary.raw: This PR allows changing the state of physics objects while simulation is paused. This means, for example, the Component Inspector will be updated after using the Transform tool while simulation is paused.
summary.html: This PR allows changing the state of physics objects while simulation is paused. This means, for example, the Component Inspector will be updated after using the Transform tool while simulation is paused.

values.description:
This PR adds support for removing sensor at runtime. I found the need for this feature while working on the ModelPropShop plugin porting \(since I couldn’t find a way to pause the camera and prevent it from creating additional images I thought I would delete it once all the images have been taken\).

The idea behind the implementation is that we will keep a map that maps ignition::sensor sensor Ids to their corresponding gazebo entities. At each PostUpdate call we iterate through the map and make sure that each entity still exists. If it doesn’t we trigger cleanup of _most_ resources \(I still didn’t find a good way to cleanup the cameras structure, I might need to introduce an additional map\).

It can be tested with my _very ugly hacky wip branch_ model\_propshop, by running

```
ign gazebo propshop.sdf -v 4 -r
```

Without the PR merged the thumbnails directory will keep getting populated with invalid images \(and the camera topic will keep being visible in the Image display plugin\).

With the PR, the thumbnails will stop being generated and the topic will stop being shown.

Now the parts where I’d be happy to get some input:

* Cleaning up the cameras structure is a bit tricky. I could change the cameras structure to a map <string, vector<Cameras> and keep the first entry of the vector as the parent and all the rest of the cameras as the children, then delete the entry only when all the cameras have been deleted. This however creates the issue, what should we do if only the parent camera of a set is deleted? Do we find a new parent? Delete the whole set? I wouldn’t even know what behavior would be acceptable in that case.
* Is the implementation idea generally OK? My first implementation iterated over the sensor list only once in the PostUpdate function but made the code in there a bit of a mess so decided to split into a separate function. Also I couldn’t find a way to do it without breaking API and introducing the new map / changing the function signature.

    



‌
values.title: Added support for removing sensors at runtime

summary.raw:
This PR adds support for removing sensor at runtime. I found the need for this feature while working on the ModelPropShop plugin porting \(since I couldn’t find a way to pause the camera and prevent it from creating additional images I thought I would delete it once all the images have been taken\).

The idea behind the implementation is that we will keep a map that maps ignition::sensor sensor Ids to their corresponding gazebo entities. At each PostUpdate call we iterate through the map and make sure that each entity still exists. If it doesn’t we trigger cleanup of _most_ resources \(I still didn’t find a good way to cleanup the cameras structure, I might need to introduce an additional map\).

It can be tested with my _very ugly hacky wip branch_ model\_propshop, by running

```
ign gazebo propshop.sdf -v 4 -r
```

Without the PR merged the thumbnails directory will keep getting populated with invalid images \(and the camera topic will keep being visible in the Image display plugin\).

With the PR, the thumbnails will stop being generated and the topic will stop being shown.

Now the parts where I’d be happy to get some input:

* Cleaning up the cameras structure is a bit tricky. I could change the cameras structure to a map <string, vector<Cameras> and keep the first entry of the vector as the parent and all the rest of the cameras as the children, then delete the entry only when all the cameras have been deleted. This however creates the issue, what should we do if only the parent camera of a set is deleted? Do we find a new parent? Delete the whole set? I wouldn’t even know what behavior would be acceptable in that case.
* Is the implementation idea generally OK? My first implementation iterated over the sensor list only once in the PostUpdate function but made the code in there a bit of a mess so decided to split into a separate function. Also I couldn’t find a way to do it without breaking API and introducing the new map / changing the function signature.

    



‌
summary.html:
This PR adds support for removing sensor at runtime. I found the need for this feature while working on the ModelPropShop plugin porting (since I couldn’t find a way to pause the camera and prevent it from creating additional images I thought I would delete it once all the images have been taken).

The idea behind the implementation is that we will keep a map that maps ignition::sensor sensor Ids to their corresponding gazebo entities. At each PostUpdate call we iterate through the map and make sure that each entity still exists. If it doesn’t we trigger cleanup of most resources (I still didn’t find a good way to cleanup the cameras structure, I might need to introduce an additional map).

It can be tested with my very ugly hacky wip branch model_propshop, by running

ign gazebo propshop.sdf -v 4 -r

Without the PR merged the thumbnails directory will keep getting populated with invalid images (and the camera topic will keep being visible in the Image display plugin).

With the PR, the thumbnails will stop being generated and the topic will stop being shown.

Now the parts where I’d be happy to get some input:

  • Cleaning up the cameras structure is a bit tricky. I could change the cameras structure to a map <string, vector<Cameras> and keep the first entry of the vector as the parent and all the rest of the cameras as the children, then delete the entry only when all the cameras have been deleted. This however creates the issue, what should we do if only the parent camera of a set is deleted? Do we find a new parent? Delete the whole set? I wouldn’t even know what behavior would be acceptable in that case.
  • Is the implementation idea generally OK? My first implementation iterated over the sensor list only once in the PostUpdate function but made the code in there a bit of a mess so decided to split into a separate function. Also I couldn’t find a way to do it without breaking API and introducing the new map / changing the function signature.

‌

values.description:
depends on the following pull requests:

* [ign-rendering pull request #252](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/252/add-support-for-setting-visibility-mask/diff)
* [ign-sensors pull request #115](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-sensors/pull-requests/115)
* [sdformat pull request #673](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/673) \(added to sdf spec 1.7\)

The changes let users use visibility mask and flags to alter the visibility of visuals for each camera. A visual is visible to a camera if `(visibility flags & visibility mask) > 0`

The user can also set the gui camera’s visibility mask through scene3d plugin params

Screenshot from `visibility.sdf`:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1992579224-visibility.png)
‌

note to self: bump dependency when a new sdformat minor version is released
values.title: Add support for visual visibility flags and camera visibility mask

values.description:
This PR fixes 2 issues:

* duplicate marker services: Two marker services of the same name is advertised when a camera sensor is present in the world, i.e. One advertised by the server and the other advertised by the gui.  So when a marker service was requested, there was undefined behavior as to where the request is handled. Fixed by prefixing the maker service topic name on server side; it’s now `/sensors/marker`. This bug might bite us again when we start supporting multiple gui’s.
* crash when the `scale` field is not set in the marker msg. The marker scale  defaulted to \[0, 0, 0\] which caused an assert error in ogre.

‌
values.title: Fix duplicate marker services and crash due to unset marker field

summary.raw:
This PR fixes 2 issues:

* duplicate marker services: Two marker services of the same name is advertised when a camera sensor is present in the world, i.e. One advertised by the server and the other advertised by the gui.  So when a marker service was requested, there was undefined behavior as to where the request is handled. Fixed by prefixing the maker service topic name on server side; it’s now `/sensors/marker`. This bug might bite us again when we start supporting multiple gui’s.
* crash when the `scale` field is not set in the marker msg. The marker scale  defaulted to \[0, 0, 0\] which caused an assert error in ogre.

‌
summary.html:
This PR fixes 2 issues:

  • duplicate marker services: Two marker services of the same name is advertised when a camera sensor is present in the world, i.e. One advertised by the server and the other advertised by the gui. So when a marker service was requested, there was undefined behavior as to where the request is handled. Fixed by prefixing the maker service topic name on server side; it’s now /sensors/marker. This bug might bite us again when we start supporting multiple gui’s.
  • crash when the scale field is not set in the marker msg. The marker scale defaulted to [0, 0, 0] which caused an assert error in ogre.

‌

values.description:
I found the dirty flag wasn't being set back to false after being checked so the grid was in a constant loop of updating after utilizing the grid plugin.

I also added some more consistent code style to reflect the rest of the file.

values.description:
When moving a static model that has a canonical link at a pose offset, the model appears to ‘jump’ by the offset amount after it’s moved.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/276981913-transform_pose_offset.gif)
‌

Turns out that the visual pose becomes inconsistent with the physics pose. The problem was that the state published back to to the scene by the system is the canonical link pose instead of the model entity pose.

Here’s the sdf of the box I used for testing:

```
    <model name="box">
      <static>true</static>
      <pose>0 0 0.0 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="box_link">
        <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
        <collision name="box_collision">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>
        <visual name="box_visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
          <material>
            <ambient>1 0 0 1.0</ambient>
            <diffuse>1 0 0 1.0</diffuse>
            <specular>1 0 0 1.0</specular>
          </material>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>
```

‌
values.title: Fix moving static model with link offset

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/276981913-transform_pose_offset.gif)

Turns out that the visual pose becomes inconsistent with the physics pose. The problem was that the state published back to to the scene by the system is the canonical link pose instead of the model entity pose.

Here’s the sdf of the box I used for testing:


summary.html:
When moving a static model that has a canonical link at a pose offset, the model appears to ‘jump’ by the offset amount after it’s moved.

‌

Turns out that the visual pose becomes inconsistent with the physics pose. The problem was that the state published back to to the scene by the system is the canonical link pose instead of the model entity pose.

Here’s the sdf of the box I used for testing:

    <model name="box">
      <static>true</static>
      <pose>0 0 0.0 0 0 0</pose>
      <link name="box_link">
        <pose>0 0 0.5 0 0 0</pose>
        <collision name="box_collision">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
        </collision>
        <visual name="box_visual">
          <geometry>
            <box>
              <size>1 1 1</size>
            </box>
          </geometry>
          <material>
            <ambient>1 0 0 1.0</ambient>
            <diffuse>1 0 0 1.0</diffuse>
            <specular>1 0 0 1.0</specular>
          </material>
        </visual>
      </link>
    </model>

‌

values.description:
The  position passed to the context menu was relative to the item so when you have a long list of entities in the entity tree, the entity context menu always pops up near the top of the entity tree widget.

Fixed by manually calculating the item offset position and adding the mouse pos to it. Not sure if that’s the best way to do it or if there is a more convenient property to get the pos from.

I accidentally pushed these changes to `ign-gazebo2` and reverted them in [f0e9d7d](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/f0e9d7d135080a9b998d52b71290ba937b49dd2f)
values.title: Fix entity tree context menu position

summary.raw:
The  position passed to the context menu was relative to the item so when you have a long list of entities in the entity tree, the entity context menu always pops up near the top of the entity tree widget.

Fixed by manually calculating the item offset position and adding the mouse pos to it. Not sure if that’s the best way to do it or if there is a more convenient property to get the pos from.

I accidentally pushed these changes to `ign-gazebo2` and reverted them in [f0e9d7d](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/commits/f0e9d7d135080a9b998d52b71290ba937b49dd2f)
summary.html:
The position passed to the context menu was relative to the item so when you have a long list of entities in the entity tree, the entity context menu always pops up near the top of the entity tree widget.

Fixed by manually calculating the item offset position and adding the mouse pos to it. Not sure if that’s the best way to do it or if there is a more convenient property to get the pos from.

I accidentally pushed these changes to ign-gazebo2 and reverted them in f0e9d7d

values.description: The physics system is requiring a feature and including components that it doesn't use.
values.title: Physics system doesn't need visuals

summary.raw: The physics system is requiring a feature and including components that it doesn't use.
summary.html: The physics system is requiring a feature and including components that it doesn't use.

values.description:
## Overview

Pull request #541 adds the ability to choose different physics engine from the command line.

This pull request builds on top of that, and reduces `MinimumFeatureList` so that physics engines are not required to implement all features, and some of them are treated as optional.

## Bullet

I've been testing this with bullet using [this ign-physics PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/134/wip-bullet-updates/diff). There's only one feature left which Bullet doesn't implement, `ConstructSdfLink`. This PR an alternative to pull request #421.

## Implementation

This PR makes the following features optional:

* Features for detachable joints:

    * `ignition::physics::AttachFixedJointFeature`
    * `ignition::physics::DetachJointFeature`
    * `ignition::physics::SetJointTransformFromParentFeature`
    
* Features for bounding box:

    * `ignition::physics::GetModelBoundingBox`
    
* Features for joint velocity commands:

    * `ignition::physics::SetJointVelocityCommandFeature`
    
* Features for 3D meshes:

    * `ignition::physics::mesh::AttachMeshShapeFeature`
    

For each group of optional features:

* Create a feature list, i.e. `DetachableJointFeatureList`
* Create entity types which use that list, i.e. `JointDetachableJointPtrType`
* Create an entity map that holds the specialized entity type, i.e. `entityJointDetachableJointMap`
* Use `entityCast` to cast from the original entity, created with `MinimumFeatureList`, to the specialized entity. `entityCast` will also populate the specialized map the first time it's called and get the entity from that map on subsequent calls. This means that `RequestFeature` is only called once for each combination of entity \+ feature list.

Any engine implementing all the minimum features will be loaded. If, at runtime, there's an attempt to use an unsupported feature, a warning is printed. That is:

* If a `component::DetachableJoint` is created, a warning is printed and the joint isn't attached or detached.
* If a `components::AxisAlignedBox` is created, a warning is printed and the box is not populated.
* If a `components::JointVelocityCmd` is created, a warning is printed and the command has no effect.
* If a collision has a mesh geometry, a warning is printed and the geometry isn't created.

---

This PR is ready for review. I'll stop looking into Bullet now and remove features not needed by TPE on a subsequent PR.
values.title: Optional physics features

summary.raw:
## Overview

Pull request #541 adds the ability to choose different physics engine from the command line.

This pull request builds on top of that, and reduces `MinimumFeatureList` so that physics engines are not required to implement all features, and some of them are treated as optional.

## Bullet

I've been testing this with bullet using [this ign-physics PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/134/wip-bullet-updates/diff). There's only one feature left which Bullet doesn't implement, `ConstructSdfLink`. This PR an alternative to pull request #421.

## Implementation

This PR makes the following features optional:

* Features for detachable joints:

    * `ignition::physics::AttachFixedJointFeature`
    * `ignition::physics::DetachJointFeature`
    * `ignition::physics::SetJointTransformFromParentFeature`
    
* Features for bounding box:

    * `ignition::physics::GetModelBoundingBox`
    
* Features for joint velocity commands:

    * `ignition::physics::SetJointVelocityCommandFeature`
    
* Features for 3D meshes:

    * `ignition::physics::mesh::AttachMeshShapeFeature`
    

For each group of optional features:

* Create a feature list, i.e. `DetachableJointFeatureList`
* Create entity types which use that list, i.e. `JointDetachableJointPtrType`
* Create an entity map that holds the specialized entity type, i.e. `entityJointDetachableJointMap`
* Use `entityCast` to cast from the original entity, created with `MinimumFeatureList`, to the specialized entity. `entityCast` will also populate the specialized map the first time it's called and get the entity from that map on subsequent calls. This means that `RequestFeature` is only called once for each combination of entity \+ feature list.

Any engine implementing all the minimum features will be loaded. If, at runtime, there's an attempt to use an unsupported feature, a warning is printed. That is:

* If a `component::DetachableJoint` is created, a warning is printed and the joint isn't attached or detached.
* If a `components::AxisAlignedBox` is created, a warning is printed and the box is not populated.
* If a `components::JointVelocityCmd` is created, a warning is printed and the command has no effect.
* If a collision has a mesh geometry, a warning is printed and the geometry isn't created.

---

This PR is ready for review. I'll stop looking into Bullet now and remove features not needed by TPE on a subsequent PR.
summary.html:
Overview

Pull request #541 adds the ability to choose different physics engine from the command line.

This pull request builds on top of that, and reduces MinimumFeatureList so that physics engines are not required to implement all features, and some of them are treated as optional.

Bullet

I've been testing this with bullet using this ign-physics PR. There's only one feature left which Bullet doesn't implement, ConstructSdfLink. This PR an alternative to pull request #421.

Implementation

This PR makes the following features optional:

  • Features for detachable joints:

    • ignition::physics::AttachFixedJointFeature
    • ignition::physics::DetachJointFeature
    • ignition::physics::SetJointTransformFromParentFeature

  • Features for bounding box:

    • ignition::physics::GetModelBoundingBox

  • Features for joint velocity commands:

    • ignition::physics::SetJointVelocityCommandFeature

  • Features for 3D meshes:

    • ignition::physics::mesh::AttachMeshShapeFeature

For each group of optional features:

  • Create a feature list, i.e. DetachableJointFeatureList
  • Create entity types which use that list, i.e. JointDetachableJointPtrType
  • Create an entity map that holds the specialized entity type, i.e. entityJointDetachableJointMap
  • Use entityCast to cast from the original entity, created with MinimumFeatureList, to the specialized entity. entityCast will also populate the specialized map the first time it's called and get the entity from that map on subsequent calls. This means that RequestFeature is only called once for each combination of entity + feature list.

Any engine implementing all the minimum features will be loaded. If, at runtime, there's an attempt to use an unsupported feature, a warning is printed. That is:

  • If a component::DetachableJoint is created, a warning is printed and the joint isn't attached or detached.
  • If a components::AxisAlignedBox is created, a warning is printed and the box is not populated.
  • If a components::JointVelocityCmd is created, a warning is printed and the command has no effect.
  • If a collision has a mesh geometry, a warning is printed and the geometry isn't created.

This PR is ready for review. I'll stop looking into Bullet now and remove features not needed by TPE on a subsequent PR.

values.description:
Splitting the forward port because Citadel is 16 PRs behind Blueprint.

This PR brings the component inspector from Blueprint to Citadel. I noticed that there was a strange behaviour when selecting links and lights on this branch, they'd just blink selected then deselect. I made some changes on 47342f8 which fixed that. @{5d114073a232e50bd6f26983} , mind double-checking that that's ok? I think we need to keep using `EntityFromNode` a bit longer.
values.title: 2 ➡️ 3 (part 1)

values.description:
depends on [ign-rendering pull request #256](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/256/support-setting-skeleton-node-weights/diff)

Integrates skeleton animation feature introduced [this ign-rendering pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/235) that lets the render engine do the animation as opposed to manually animating the skeleton bone poses.

The manual update mode still works and can be controlled by changing the `actorManualSkeletonUpdate` bool variable in `RenderUtil.cc`. We could use a component for setting this behavior in the future.

The integration is more involved than I had hoped. Most of the logic is for syncing skeleton animation with trajectory animation. Unfortunately I still had to manually calculate the root bone pose every iteration in order to sync the two. It involves computing the correct point in time the skeleton animation is to be played when interpolate\_x is on.
values.title: Actor skeleton animation (auto update mode)

summary.raw:
depends on [ign-rendering pull request #256](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/256/support-setting-skeleton-node-weights/diff)

Integrates skeleton animation feature introduced [this ign-rendering pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-rendering/pull-requests/235) that lets the render engine do the animation as opposed to manually animating the skeleton bone poses.

The manual update mode still works and can be controlled by changing the `actorManualSkeletonUpdate` bool variable in `RenderUtil.cc`. We could use a component for setting this behavior in the future.

The integration is more involved than I had hoped. Most of the logic is for syncing skeleton animation with trajectory animation. Unfortunately I still had to manually calculate the root bone pose every iteration in order to sync the two. It involves computing the correct point in time the skeleton animation is to be played when interpolate\_x is on.
summary.html:
depends on ign-rendering pull request #256

Integrates skeleton animation feature introduced this ign-rendering pull request that lets the render engine do the animation as opposed to manually animating the skeleton bone poses.

The manual update mode still works and can be controlled by changing the actorManualSkeletonUpdate bool variable in RenderUtil.cc. We could use a component for setting this behavior in the future.

The integration is more involved than I had hoped. Most of the logic is for syncing skeleton animation with trajectory animation. Unfortunately I still had to manually calculate the root bone pose every iteration in order to sync the two. It involves computing the correct point in time the skeleton animation is to be played when interpolate_x is on.
